title: CVE-2018-17144 Duplicate Input Inflation Bug
summary: A regression in duplicate-input checks created a potential inflation and denial-of-service risk.
details: Certain Bitcoin Core versions could accept transactions with duplicate inputs in a way that threatened consensus safety. If exploited in a mined block, this could have created invalid inflation or destabilized node behavior.
impact: Potential inflation and consensus instability if exploited on chain.
mitigations: Upgrade to patched Bitcoin Core releases (0.16.3+).
Maintain conservative node upgrade and review procedures.
Use defense-in-depth testing for transaction validation paths.

title: Pre-SegWit Transaction Malleability
summary: Before SegWit, txid-sensitive workflows were vulnerable to third-party transaction ID mutation.
details: Legacy transaction serialization allowed mutations in signature-related fields that changed txid without changing economic intent. This complicated unconfirmed tracking and protocol overlays dependent on txid stability.
impact: Operational failures, accounting confusion, and higher complexity for second-layer protocol design.
mitigations: Use wtxid-aware tooling and robust confirmation logic.
Avoid relying on unconfirmed txid assumptions in critical flows.

title: 2010 Value Overflow Incident
summary: An integer overflow bug allowed creation of an invalid inflation transaction.
details: A validation bug in early Bitcoin software failed to reject a transaction whose outputs exceeded valid monetary bounds due to integer overflow behavior. The incident was corrected via emergency patching and chain rollback coordination.
impact: Temporary supply-rule violation and urgent ecosystem intervention.
mitigations: Strict monetary range checks in validation code.
Conservative release engineering for consensus-critical code.
